Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: When Social Isolation Leads to Loneliness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the situational factors that intensify or inhibit feelings of loneliness while alone are investigated and individual differences (e.g., introversion) that modify this process are identified. Despite the significant effect loneliness can have on health, there is still much that is unknown about its causes. Specifically, little is known about when social isolation will (and will not) evoke feelings of loneliness. For example, throughout the day, people typically move in and out of social isolation--perhaps an individual eats breakfast with his or her partner and then drives to work, alone. It is unclear from existing research if we should expect this person to feel any lonelier during this solitary drive than he or she felt while eating. Identifying the situational and individual risk-factors for loneliness may have wide-ranging benefits. This project has the potential to advance national health and welfare by indicating how people can maximize the benefit of their social behavior, as well as by strengthening behavioral interventions to reduce feelings of loneliness.

For this project, data will be collected from approximately 700 participants sampled from a demographically diverse group of online workers. Each participant will complete a survey and multiple time diaries using a web-based platform. In the time diaries, participants will report about their daily experiences in chunks of time oriented around "activities" (e.g., sleeping, driving to work, eating lunch) and they will record other information regarding these blocks of time (e.g., who they were with and the emotions they experienced). This time diary will capture moments of social isolation, feelings of loneliness during such isolation, and the contextual details expected to intensify or inhibit feelings of loneliness. The importance of these contextual details will be identified via appropriate statistical analyses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thanks to support from the NSF DDRIG, R. Gordon Rinderknecht has completed his dissertation, ?Factors Contributing to the Experience of State Loneliness?. During the funding period, Gordon refined a time-diary instrument he previously programmed, collected data using this instrument, analyzed this data, and is in the process of disseminating the results of his dissertation research which seeks to provide greater understanding of the sources of loneliness in daily life (i.e., state loneliness). These results demonstrate how the expectation to be social influences feelings of state loneliness while alone, how the nature of social engagement and the kind of person engaged with jointly influence the benefit of the engagement for avoiding state loneliness, and how work-schedule conflict may heighten state loneliness experienced in the presence of partners.

This research extends the sociological knowledge about loneliness and social isolation by contributing to a small but growing literature on the daily experience of loneliness. Most research on isolation and loneliness focuses on how lonely people feel they are in general, not in any particular moment in time. This research is useful for showing how demographic factors that shape the quality and quantity of network ties influence general perception of loneliness (e.g., education, employment status, marital status). However, these factors are difficult to build interventions around. Rather than focusing on general feelings of loneliness, Gordon focused on changes in state loneliness across a day via three related but separate analyses. Focusing on situational sources of state loneliness is valuable because it may provide opportunities for interventions.

First, Gordon proposed that the times, activities, and locations where loneliness would be most prevalent while isolated would be those in which people felt the greatest expectation to be social. Findings support this prediction for time but not activity or location. Next, past research focuses on the importance of social engagement for avoiding loneliness but not the different forms this engagement can take?e.g., direct ?active? engagement and ?passive? co-presence. Gordon proposes and finds that active engagement is more beneficial than passive engagement for avoiding state loneliness, and that this benefit of active over passive engagement is most beneficial when engaging with weak ties, relative to strong ties. Lastly, Gordon proposes that work-schedule conflict would degrade the relationship quality of romantic partners, undercutting the value of partner engagement for avoiding state loneliness. As expected, increasing work-schedule conflict associated with greater loneliness when engaging with partners, but this appears to be largely unrelated to changes in relationship quality.

The project also contributes to the methodology of studying time use via time diaries. Studying how state loneliness changes throughout a day is challenging due to participants? difficulty recalling such feelings. Gordon developed a time diary that makes collecting state loneliness and other situational factors (e.g., who else is present and where the participant was located) convenient for participants and usable with participants recruited online. This platform performed well and is currently in use studying the effects of COVID-19 on time use and wellbeing.

This research has been invited into the 2020 Time Use Across the Life Course conference. Although originally scheduled for June, it is currently being rescheduled due to COVID-19. The research has also been presented as part of Gordon?s dissertation, completed July 2020. One chapter is currently in revise and resubmit status at Social Problems. Gordon plans to revise the other chapters for publication in academic outlets and disseminate the research in both academic and non-academic venues.
